review_title: The grass is not always greener...
pros:
A lot of learning. Exposure.
Speaking with C level Executives of Fortune 500 Companies.
cons: Too much to know in the time they want you to know it in.  Sales is based heavily on luck. I have seen some of the hardest workers get surpassed by those that don't do much just because they hit their number. (You can hit your number in so many ways, its unfair to grade everyone on the same scale when we have different territories, field reps, people to work with)

review_title: Great people, but don't expect to EVER get a raise
pros: Great people, products, facilities, and overall comfort working at the company.  The company is accommodating, has great benefits, and flexibility.
cons: It is next to impossible to get a raise.  The employer may give you a promotion with no additional compensation.  Just to clarify, there is no cost of living increase either.

pros:
Individual roles are well defined and there is independence to certain extent.
You can do as many certifications as you want on Oracle products, for FREE!
cons:
No pre defined career goal. Managers are mostly clueless about the same as well.
No raise or hike for 3 years now in many LOBs.
No transparency on communication relating to financial matters.
HR is mostly stuck on policies and rarely uses their brains.
Like all Indian companies, tendency to exploit employees to the max.

pros: Flexibility, options to learn and Oracle is a market place in itself where you can move around to other jobs. Highly dynamic in nature and keeps changing fast which gives all the fun of being in Oracle.
cons: Some management areas are very bad especially the GFIC under Safra Catz. I was under Safra but now moved under Thomas Kurian which is a fun place to be. Salary is a huge concern and donest get hikes very often. Promotions doesnt come with hikes. facilities are below average being a company like Oracle.

pros: flexible schedule. good work/life balance. in sync with the industry. decent perks and benefits. good culture. nice diversity.
cons: compensation is below the market average. raises and bonuses just do not exist. you can literally spend years before any adjustment to your compensation takes place. and when it does, it's usually an insult. like 0.7 % every 6 years. if you're lucky. so all in all, you end up with the pay cut every year due to normal inflation.

review_title: Great career as team lead, senior manager, director and software architect for many years of company growth.
pros:
- Always a challenge and something interesting to work on.
- Continual availability of new responsibilities to take on and grow into.
- Work that's so interesting and varied that I have never want to leave to work elsewhere.
- Great compensation and benefits. Great rewards, recognition and acknowledgement for excellent performance and doing outstanding work. Very motivating!
- Great people, with a pretty flat organizational structure, redirect by peers regardless of level, and not a single Prima Donna. No naysayers or downtalkers polluting the culture. 
- Great collaborative atmosphere and lots of help available as you learn and grow.
- Well managed, smoothly running, efficient processes on engineering teams create the right amount of pressure, with never a dull moment.
- Ample resources and opportunities to learn and grow.
- With experience, you'll get increased access to executives and leaders to share ideas
- really fun "hack weeks" and opportunities to invent and innovate.
- very good work life balance. No questions asked personal days. PTO as you need it (merit-influenced) without having to accrue days, no limit if you responsibly get your work done ahead of time and arrange for backup support while you're away.
- offices around the world, and opportunities to travel to amazing places for collaboration with teams abroad.
cons:
- no good mass transit options to the San Mateo office location. Most people drive, some bike.
- sometimes you must work really early or really late hours due to meetings with international teams. But you can shift your work time around to accommodate.
- not a lot of on campus amenities. Not a lot of catered food. You bring your own food usually, and take care of personal business at home. It's not google. But you're not pressured to "live at work"

pros: very veryy good self train opportunity. lovely people. good clients. processes extremely clear. good reputation of the company when you go to other clients for projects.
cons: they clearly, when I say they I mean upper management, do not promote success. Very business oriented and only care about sales.

pros: Oracle is a truly exciting place to work in, especially with the cloud developments, digital transformations and AI and big data revolution. Lots of opportunities and lots of possibilities to add value, very interesting customer projects and digital transformations where Oracle is involved in. It is very much a 'self service' organization, with a lot on offer, and where you yourself shape your career. Very international, very intercultural, very dynamic, very professional. Really impressive and professional, very 'lean' organization, pragmatic. Love it!
cons: Very big organization so takes a while to find your way

job_title: Senior Business Operations Manager in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Flexible schedule & ability to work from home. Long term stability (depending on the team). Quality benefits & cost is reasonable for employee only (cost is high for family). Good manager (experience can vary greatly depending on what team you work for). Good camaraderie among co-workers.
cons: Pay is typically below the market & raises are often non-existent. Not a lot of long term growth potential. You have to leave the company and come back in order to make a competitive salary.

job_title: Master Principal Sales Consultant in Brandon, FL
pros: No Micro management, Flexible hours, great benefits. The tech teams are the smartest and brightest I've ever met in the industry.
cons: Every Year it's like being in a startup.  Fast to respond to changing business and Technology trends. Growing pains in the cloud space can be frustrating..

review_title: Big company culture; squash the entrepreneurial thinker
pros: There are opportunities to move within the company.  Employee benefits are pretty good.  They were supportive of funding training and certifications.
cons: Oracle purchased our very successful medium-sized business and within two years managed to un-delight most of our customers.  Releasing software is a royal pain and takes a very long time.  Too many unfounded rules.  PTO plan for long-term employees is not very good - you max out at 5 years.

pros:
Loved working with my Tekelec co-workers, at least the few that remained after the many rounds of layoffs after we were acquired by Oracle in 2013.

They do did have good medical and dental benefits as well as generous sick time and holidays with industry standard level of vacation.
cons: One Oracle took over in 2013 and Tekelec completely lost it's start up mentality which is what made it so great place to work. If you want to work for a large corp. with very stringent layers of development rules and processes for everything, this is the place for you.

pros: The people are great, work/life balance and continuous learning are encouraged. In the product group, you have to work hard and are accountable, but you're also given independence and autonomy.
cons: With the switchover to Oracle there are more processes and you feel like a new employee again. Massage therapy is one of the few benefits I use, and with Oracle that was cut back to much less than the market standard.

job_title: Principal Member Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
No probation period.
No attendance check
cons:
1. Manager and Higher rank employees marching towards Money, not innovation.
2. Most managers will talk in Hindi.
3. Priority is given to 3+ years experience peoples.
4. No hike in 3 years.
5. Will not accept new technology update, the manager only follow its higher authority.
6. The manager will take care about is fellow team members.
7. The manager will work hard for his L1 and H1 manager visa.
8. The manager will not conduct the yearly review,  he will just put his own rating.
9. Oracle HR will support managers, so your queries are eyewash.
10. Most of the managers are 40+, so it is like a government office.
11. A manager will have his own set of people they will be promoted first.

pros: Great Training system, huge learning opportunities, unlimited growth opportunities internally  in different depts or roles, good CSR culture, great to attract talent
cons: Poor talent retention system, salary promotions very difficult after you enter, change in culture  in the last 3 yrs very negative and backstabbing, very inflexible processes, they forgot totally about the coaching culture, HR dept overloaded and very little help for employees.  Several cases of management abuse

pros: Amazing benefits, some wonderful coworkers.
cons: Never ending drudgery of status updates and time tracking. Going into the office felt like my soul was being sucked out of my body. Raises are pitiful if you're lucky enough to get one (because managers are not allowed to give raises to the entire team). I was part of the annual layoff despite being a high performer. Oracle doesn't bother trying to fit you in with other teams, but after laying you off they'll send you a letter identifying job openings. If you get rehired, you have to give back your severance.

pros:
If you have earrings to do (your kids school, paying some services, call to fix something at home...) you may ask to arrive late or leave the office earlier that day.

Oracle is self service oriented, so sometimes you need to push for what you want (career development) instead of "waiting for your manager to decide". This may be considered a CON by a few people. 

In Mexico you may find a more friendly environment, so you may speak about your career, suggesting new ideas to your peers, and ask for help.

You will find respect and you always can ask for it if it is lost somehow.

If you are one of the top performers within your team, and this is noticed by your peers and your management, then you should be rewarded (raise, stock). 
Depending on your job requirements, you may ask to work from home (home office), how many days depends on how you negotiate it and how responsible you are.

You may find a great team to be part of. Some teams share a lot, within and without of the office.

Free coffee, free snacks (fruit, juice, cereal, cookies for those that arrive early to the office), ping pong tables, foosball, great variety of clubs (sports, dancing, chess, toastmasters, yoga and others).
cons:
Depending on the organization (team, or manager) you may or not have an appraisal. There is the option to fill one professional review per year and have it in the HR system, but some teams do not use it at all, or fill it with the bare minimum , so you may or may not use this "appraisal score" as a tool in your favor to request a a raise or promotion. 

If your manager is not in site, you may need to adapt to remote leadership, and expect 1 or 2 visits from them (one week, each one) per year. 

As in any job, if your manager and you do not fit, then you may want to look for some other opportunities (in fact, you can start by joining other team at oracle, instead of leaving the company). But if you find a cool manager, then take advantage of the situation so you can trust a person who helps you to grow.

review_title: Good salary, nice colleagues, poor management
job_title: Inside Sales Account Executive in Dublin, Dublin
pros: Excellent career development, solid salary, good responsibility. It is a huge organisation where you can always find support or help.
cons: 7 changes of manager over two years, territory kept changing. Cons of such a huge organisation is that it is hard to get things done, unless you follow the standard procedure exactly. Bid part of the job is learning how to deal with internal politics and systems that are there to "help you".

pros:
- Good colleagues
- Good benefits
- Good atmosphere
- Healthcare
- Work life balance is good
cons:
- Intranet is a mess, can't find anything on it
- Latest selling Oracle technology is not available for dev teams naturally, cumbersome approval process for it
- Yearly goals are not really set and tracked, advancement process is shady at best
- Salaries never increase unless you rank up / change position which is not discussed how to do so
- Dev team is spread out around the entire globe from west US to India, makes cooperation very ineffective

review_title: Great company if you are a goal-driven and enthusiastic individual
pros:
international corporate with a huge range of different departments all over the world
self-service - you are able to build your career
training offers and personal development
outside of office events
great benefits
cons:
in such a big company, it is essential to have a voice and use it - you are the builder of your success and career
internal processes might lead to slow down certain actions

review_title: Depends on what org you are in
pros: Great training and opportunity for recent grads, can move up quickly, tons of opportunity.
cons:
Such a large company creates a lot of confusion about what is going on and internal politics between many reps being mapped to the same account can cause conflict.

Some organizations are less successful than other, not a con, just be weary that often your org can determine how successful you will be.

Very old school values in terms of work life balance, not much WFH in my experience ( though usually depends on manager).

pros: No pros except an I card which has a oracle logo on it
cons:
There is no work life balance. People are working on very outdated technologies and not even trying to shift to newer ones. Management is very bad. Your boss will expect you to spend 9-10 hours daily. They don't have new clients. Appraisal are very bad. You will not get paid enough for what you do. Higher management is worse. They treat ICs like labour's. They don't have a proper way to talk. They don't have proper knowledge of SDLC.
In short don't go for this company specially OBP dev team.

review_title: You make what you put in, exactly like life is!
pros:
Leadership have goals that are clear, Management will put a strategy in place and will offer the tactics to fulfil these.  If you have better tactics speak up and ask for investment and you will get it, have seen some silly ideas nurtured as well which is brilliant. Come up with a recipe or follow whats offered as gold standard. Plenty room, investment and support offered to test out ideas. 

Training and Support second to none, 

Training, Days, Months and Years worth free online training content available to suckle on. Most FLMs would almost NEVER say no to a training course if you have had it in your Personal Development Plan and aligns to the Goals set for yourself at the start of the year. Do contribute before you start demanding courses though. If you are prescribed a course by L&D, GO DO IT, there will always be 1 thing that you could pick up. 

 
Support. every FLM and Leader in OD, OU and BDG has real experience in Sales and has seen success at smaller or greater degree. There was a time when promotions were offered as confetti not any more, most first line managers are directly involved in deals which helps with internal and external selling. 

Exactly like life, you will find ups and downs! Like they say, calm waters never make a seasoned sailor!
cons:
Pay rises are not known of, the only way to get pay rises is by over performing, making to club or get closer to quota/ target and make a pay rise an embarrassment for your Manager.  

Promotion doesn't always mean pay rise so negotiate well at the start of the tenure. 

Current circumstances [COVID-19] will test the digital-ability of Oracle Digital.

review_title: Great for people who are focused on making sales, regardless on wether the customer needs it.
pros: Some good technology acquisitions, although its not easy to see if or how they will be integrated.
cons: Very focused on the Database. Culturally finds it difficult to accept that the sales process is very different form Database and addons, to most of what they have acquired in the middleware or application tiers.

job_title: Development Manager in Redwood City, CA
pros: It's a big company, so there are options to choose from - moving groups is possible, even changing career tracks (Engineer to PM, etc.) is a possibility. The company is stable and won't be going away soon :) - as long you are doing a good job, there is little worry that you'll be laid off. The health and 401(k) benefits are generally decent. As always - combination of  right place, right time, hard work, positive energy will pay off in the long term - have a 5 year + window.
cons:
Its big! So a lot of people seem lost.
My knowledge is limited to Fusion Middleware (Application Server) platform area and cannot comment of DB or APPS teams - the problems are 
- dysfunctional - there is the  obvious "right arm doesn't know what left arm is doing" syndrome.
- SDLC is not strictly followed -- engineering process gets a little chaotic/ ad hoc. the initial set of requirements/restrictions that you start with almost never hold true. Some thing or the other will change and you'll have to accommodate for it. 
- schedules are very aggressive but in my opinion not realistic. To give an example, product hasn't shipped 18 months after a previously advertised "code freeze" date.
- you work a lot but get a sense of not having achieved as much. 
- if you like to code a lot, then this isn't the place :(
- nobody makes firm commitments on requirements/schedules - I guess it is a way to make sure anything you don't know now can be made a "requirement" later.

review_title: Great company for work/life balance - not so good for professional growth.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Bangalore
pros:
There are several reasons for which Oracle could be rated as a good company, and here a few of these:

1. Freedom at work place, nobody (including the managers) would ask for any tight and unrealistic deadlines. The delivery of the work is what matters. In fact there is no attendance register and no regulations over breaks, e.g. cigarette :)

2. Flexible working hours, which gives the employees to be able to take time off when it is necessary. Also, it is good facilities and the employees do not try to be unfair to the company, and rather don't crib when they have to complete the work even when they have to work for late hours.

3. Work at home, (to most of the people) which is one of the most exciting gift an employer could give to an employee, who could choose to be at home when (s)he is not keeping well (to drive/commute), has some personal work (Dr. appointments etc.), bad weather.

4. Good working environment, people behave quite professionally here and knowledge is shared freely.

5. Excellent business processes and ethics programs.

6. Hiring process is good (not the best, though) and some very smart people work here.

7. Future appears bright with the smart acquisitions, which have resulted in good profits.
cons:
Yes, there are some:

1. Being a product company, employee (at least in the development) feel relaxed, and probably do not add much to their core knowledge (programing etc.), although they do develop their domain and product knowledge.

2. Training, very little focus in this area.

3. Information regarding yearly bonus/hikes are kept as a top-secret.

4. The chances to go up the ladder is lesser here.

review_title: Love the flexible schedule and benefits - and the people are awesome too.
job_title: Senior Member of Technical Staff in Nashua, NH
pros: Oracle has great compensation packages.  Even though they don't like to purchase hardware, Oracle is willing to raise your salary out of band if they really value you.  The people here are great.  Oracle has a culture of valuing independent contributions and ideas.  This leads to you being able to work as much or as little as you like, within the limits of reason, of course.  Oracle offers great work\life balance, with flexible hours, telecommuting, and other small perks.   The best part of it all is that the managers at Oracle are all excellent.  Oracle tends to promote managers from technical people, so they understand the work that you do.  You don't need to go management to make cash though - Oracle offers a technical track which rewards technical people just as much.  In addition to all this, Oracle has an awesome HQ, with gym, pool, etc.
cons: Lack of interest in purchasing hardware - makes it very hard to develop code when you can't access hardware.  I often spend my time waiting for a process to finish when I could have been done in half the time with more disk space, faster machine, etc.  When you consider the cost of hardware versus my time, its very short sited.  Also, like many companies, Oracle will take all you have to give and than ask for more.  Performance feedback is also very lacking.  I've been here 4 years and gotten 1 formal review.  In addition to this, getting hired at Oracle can take some time, sometimes people have to wait a long time (up to a year) for Larry to approve their offer....  yes, that Larry.  All job offers go through Larry Ellison at some point.  (In fact, lots of things do.  Its very much like a small company in that way.)

review_title: A good day at Oracle is when you don't get fired or laid off
pros:
great on the resume, most are impressed with the company
financially successful company
if you don't want to work too hard, it's good, but don't expect much for career development
great place for women with children and working from home
cons:
employees don't share in the financial success of the company
very employee unfriendly, no sat surveys, performance reviews not required, it's like working in a prision. and if you don't like it, it's fine with them for you to leave.

pros: Great benefits.  I've worked at many companies in the Bay Area and by far Oracle has the best benefits I have ever seen too bad it didn't last longer.  I was at a company acquired by Oracle and was laid-off.  They honored the acquired companies severance agreement quickly.  In addition, even though they laid me off they gave me a prorated bonus based on the acquired companies terms.  I thought this was fair. think Oracle acquirse and lay-off so frequently they have a very good process in place and are run like a machine.
cons:
I was at a company that was hired by Oracle and helped them integrate information for a few months as an Oracle employee with full health benefits and 401(k).  It seemed a bit strange to get this for a few months, but not much makes sense in the corporate world.   I did not work in Redwood City.  I never saw one Oracle employee come to our office.  I worked by e-mail and on the phone with Oracle counterparts.  It seemed a bit impersonal.  Also, I was confused as what to do the last day I was there.  There was a lack of communication around how to turn in your badge and laptop.  I inquired the last minute and was told to just leave everything at the desk.  There was no exit interview by HR or even any signed paper work.  Oracle seemed very impersonal and did not seem to care about employees that they did not deem essential.  This wasn't the first time I was laid-off by a large corporation and comparatively speaking Oracle lacked sensitivity.

In addition, there was very poor communication around the acquisition process leaving employees nervous.

review_title: People leaving primesourcing division at very high rate.
pros:
Good work culture 
Not much pressure, They are not cheap.. decent people.
cons: Top level management is direction less. They don't really bother about the employees. Now after Oracle takeover situation is much confused. Recently they announced some "correction" of salaries, but were cunning enough to raise the variable segment only that is very less and no one knows when they will give it. The appraisal system here is really illogical and indicates that sycophancy pays. After self appraisal some ratings are give by supervisors, again at the time when hike will be given you will come to know about your ratings (L1 to L5). But no one knows the connection between the two. Also in PrimeSourcing division they think after a certain level of experience you are required to move in management. It means this is not the right place for someone who is looking for innovative technical work. Senior guys keep on adding years to their experience though technically they may not be of any use. So many managers are there, one will wonder what do they really manage.. i think they manage how to remain there without doing any worthy task. But this story is more or less same with India's software service industry, this is not alone.

review_title: Reasonable place to work depending on who and what group you work in
job_title: Applications Sales Manager in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Excellent medical benefits that are very generous.  Large company with staying power and continued growth in the future.  Potential ability to move into new roles if you are motivated
cons: Overspecialization of the sales force causes negative customer relationships.   Many conflicting agendas to continually navigate.   Poor pay for internally promoted people

review_title: Thank you for the years of service. Now get out!
pros:
Flexible schedule depending upon the project needs
Telecommuting is encouraged if possible 
Excellent team of people I directly worked with
Good benefits
cons:
Team culture touted is to run like a start-up, but with all the constraints of working within a large company, so accomplishing team goals can be difficult to impossible.
Laid off after eight years of excellent service with a FedEx package sent to my home with little explanation.

review_title: An OK place, easy to get lost in the shuffle
pros:
- Lots of smart people.
- Good overall technology to work with.
- Good way to get started in business software.
- Can have good work/life balance if you sacrifice advancement.
cons:
- Huge company.
- Little recognition for positive achievement.
- Salary falls behind market level over time.
- Crunch times can be intense and schedules are managed poorly.
- Little emphasis on continued learning and career development.

review_title: Positve energy flows at work place
job_title: Senior Member Tech Staff in Bangalore
pros:
- Flexible work culture.
- Good medical and other Miscellaneous benefits for employees
- Decent Pay package when compared to market standards
cons:
- Most of the Sr management, I worked with, is not competent enough in terms of technology and management. 
-Mostly I encountered old timers as managers in the company who like to play safe and stay at the top by introducing internal politics with in the teams.

review_title: Many great people working under oppressive policies and management
pros: Oracle has very good products, a strong market reputation, and a deep install base, which helps as a salesperson, because clients generally have reasons to see me, and most have some level of respect for the company.  Their benefits package is strong.
cons: Oracle is run by a relatively small group of people, and if you are not in the club, you don't stand a chance of going far in your career.  As they apparently don't trust their middle level managers, the vast majority of decisions/approvals, whether related to employees or client deals, have to be made at the level of the Oracle president.  Almost every deal a salesperson puts together, goes to the president's office for approval.  There have been no raises in the past five years at the "regular" employee level despite quarter after quarter record earnings, and they are using "dry" promotions (title promotion with no monetary increase) as a matter of course.  Oracle's internal business governance policies demonstrate either extreme risk aversion, paranoia, or both, making it very difficult to get business done, frustrating clients and employees.  Nearly every client has told me that Oracle is the most difficult firm to deal with - I can't disagree.

review_title: Work life balance is the only thing u will find wonderful in oracle.
pros:
1.Salaries for freshers and while joining the company is bit higher than the market average.
2.Less work, life would be very cool if you don't want to work.
3.Work from home option for employees.
4.Work life balance excellent.
cons:
1.Less career growth.(very few oppoutunities for promotion)
2.Dont expect hikes(negotiate higher salary while joining the company)
3.Will get bonus only if ur business unit is doing good.
4.People come to Oracle to relax.
5.Dont have much challenging work./No onsite.

review_title: not a good place to start your career with
pros: good brand name, opportunity to work with awesome new technology, best place to learn about the horizontals and grow into technical consultant role
cons: non competitive compensation policies, low scope of work visibility across teams, freshers get more than experienced in the same team without considering for hike of experienced developers, no US/HQ visits to interact with other teams

pros: Always nice to work for a highly successful company that in many ways area ahead of and leading the market. Hard work is expected and expectations are set high - but achievements are awarded
cons: Oracle is very big in size, revenue, number of customers, employees, revenue and profits and growth: Part of the recipe for succes is strict processes to ensure that it continues to operate consistently and effectively through its continues growth; That makes Oracle process heavy; Takes some getting used to if you are used to work in a small company, but it works

review_title: Not bad, yet could be better
pros:
Excellent infrastructure
Process oriented
Some technical stalwarts to work with and learn from
cons:
Pay scale is way below
Hikes are unfair
Products division given more preference and importance than the Services arm
HR has no say whatsoever... All controls with delivey heads.
HR highly inefficient. No one cares to give you the right information. 
Use of delaying tactics and non trasperency on appriasals is a regular with HR
Appriasals take too much of time. Open in April close in August without arrears

review_title: You are either lucky or dissatisfied !!
pros: Great place to get started with your career. Lot of opportunities to learn provided you get into their Primesourcing group. You are almost certain to get into development and in a year's time you will realize the jump start you have on your mates from college in terms of technical knowledge and exposure. But, if you get into their product development, it becomes a gamble. You might end up being someone with domain expertise with a handsome salary or someone with nothing at all. Nevertheless, not many will regret the decision to join the company as a fresher. Laterals might also not find an issue as they pay them well. But, if you are an employee who has joined the company and has been there for 2 years or more, you will feel the heat !!
cons: Compensation is pathetic, particularly Primesourcing group !! There is always a difference in treatment when it comes to treating employees from different groups (primesourcing, product development etc) !! Some really bizarre policies they have. The appraisal policy is a mockery ! Oracle acquisition hasn't helped. They earn projects using the Oracle brand name, assure quality of Oracle standards, but the employee salary is less than1/2 of what an Oracle India employee earns ! here is the best part -- People with 2+ years of experience earn almost the same as a fresher !!! review_title: A black hole of experience with good benefits
pros: Decent benefits, Paid overtime due to hourly rate, travel benefits (if you like travel), good coworkers, paid certifications.
cons:
In the context of this review I am specifically talking about being an Associate Consultant out of the Reston Delivery Center (RDC). The ability to grow within the company is almost non-existent. The RDC exists purely to provide cheap support labor. I would say 20-25% of people actually are able to grow within the company. It will take generally take 2-3 years before you get your first (minimal) raise and promotion.

What is worse is the opportunity to gain knowledge. They might bring you in as a 'developer' but there is a good chance you won't actually develop. They will put you on testing or some sort of sysadmin role for one of their many products if they can get you on a project. And that is if you even get on a project. It is not uncommon for you to sit on the bench for upwards of 6-10 months your first year on the job. And after a month you will be frustrated because you just want to be useful. And none of this is useful when talking to other companies because they care less about testing experience or bench time and would rather see a product you have built. It is essentially an experience black hole unless you are working on your own side projects.

And for 20%-40% this will lead to other things. They will get actual developing experience and maybe even get a promotion and start going up some sort of ladder before another company agrees to pay a lot more money for you. But a job shouldn't have a 20%-40% success rate. 

My conclusion is if you have other offers, do not go to Oracle RDC. Other companies will help you grow as a person way more than Oracle. But if you have to go to Oracle it is not the worst thing in the world. Just always have a side project. Always be looking outside the company. And leave for a better company when you can.

cons:
Where to begin.... Oracle is MASSIVE. I can only assume this is what it is like working for the government (which is not something I would ever want to do). The bloat, the waste, the offshore teams, no raises,  the incredible lack of flexibility are just the tips of the iceberg. 

A multitude of sales people get compensated on deals that they did nothing to help support/close (and may not even truly know the customer very well). I don't mean just a manager, I mean many sales people which is just a HUGE waste of money. The sales teams push on everyone to get a deal done when they don't held the deal get done, didn't help setup the deal, and only are pushing so they get paid (again even though they didn't lift a finger to close the deal). The processes in place are so inflexible that customers and employees pay dearly for it. 

I could go on and on, but will leave you with this. The company culture is one I have never experienced before. Truly I feel the vast majority of folks at Oracle are out for themselves alone and don't give a rat's you know what about fellow employees or the customers. This breeds negativity that permeates throughout the company which is the ultimate reason I chose to leave. Don't get me wrong, everyone has to think about themselves and their families, but folks at Oracle take it to limits I have never seen and I have worked at a number of companies, both large and small.

job_title: Applications Sales Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
My goal of this review is to be unbiased and give the facts from what I have experienced in my 1-2 years as an ASR.

Pros:
Work/Life Balance
Networking
Career Opportunities and progression
Good company to have on resume
cons:
The Position:
The ASR role really is not a sales position and should not be called as such. ASR's spend almost 90% of their time cold calling and prospecting, with the other 10% doing paperwork for their field rep counterparts. I will say that ASRs can and do close their own deals. This is uncommon as many field reps can and will take every deal found by an ASR and work it themselves, leaving the ASR to do more prospecting and paperwork. As for metrics, ASRs are required to submit every single interaction they have with their customers, whether it's a phone call or email. This is not how sales should work.

Quota's:
Quota's are obtainable, but this requires a good territory that is performing, which is a flip of a coin. In my pillar, 85% of the ASR's did not hit their numbers and the ones who did either had a great field rep or they were in a great territory.

Compensation:
The compensation is probably my biggest con with Oracle. When I was hired, I was told that I would reach my total compensation number (Base + Commission) if I hit 100% of my quota - sounds fair to me. But no, that is not realistic as after 1 week I received my commission rate, did some math, and realized if I hit 100% of my number I would only make about half of my total commission pay. This is the main reason I am writing this review, as I strongly feel that I was lied to by the hiring managers to get me on board. 

Overall, I would ONLY recommend the role of an ASR to recent college graduates to get good experience with a Fortune 100 company. If you're a current Oracle ASR reading this - my suggestion is to get 1-2 and then work hard to get into one of the up and coming cloud companies. If you are/were a sales representative for a good company and considering Oracle, please - do not bite on their compensation structure as it is very misleading. There are much, much better companies out there with better sales programs.

Since Oracle acquired more than 100+ companies which includes small popular enterprises such as Retek,Logic and some large tech giants such as Sun Microsystems , People soft , ATG and recently Netsuite and LogFire.

pros:
-Pay isn't horrible unless your territory/team is absolute garbage. I made around 70k overall before taxes -- which isn't a bad salary right out of college

-Good exposure to the IT space if you don't have any experience. You'll learn a ton about cloud, database, certain apps, analytics, and the whole IT landscape in general. It's a skillset that transfers very nicely into better sales jobs at other companies 

-Good name brand recognition -- Oracle SDR's/AE's have a relatively easy time moving to superior companies like Salesforce, Google, Amazon, or to high-paying startups. 

-Nice gym that you can use for free.
cons:
Where do I even begin...

-Incredibly fake, fratty culture. If you aren't obsessed with baseball, weren't in a sorority, don't go to certain trendy bars, etc you won't like the other people here. The SDR force is completely recruited from a couple frats in a few California schools. Simply put, the people here suck. Everyone who is genuinely curious and intelligent is trying their hardest to get out if they're already here. 

-Awful, infuriating bureaucracy and technology. The CRM that you'll be using is a piece of trash. Actually, that's insulting to trash. It's the worst piece of technology I've ever used in my life. It's slow, crashes constantly, is completely counter intuitive, and annoys everyone who has to use it. A lot of websites and resources that you'll need to work on the job are similarly slow and incredibly buggy. 

-The product you'll probably be selling (Oracle Cloud) is a piece of trash. Comparing this to its "competitors" (Azure, AWS) is like comparing a Game Boy Color to a Oculus headset.  It is slow, the documentation sucks, its sales are drastically declining, and it frequently crashes and breaks. I felt bad selling this abomination. Its only redeeming value is that it is cheap. 

-Incredibly cheap company. No shuttle buses, no free food, depressing gray office, completely unwilling to invest in things that make work there pleasant. The leadership can afford it, they just don't care. 

-Oracle in general is a failing company that is getting left in the dust by its competitors. There's a lot of nonsense about how they're going to "kill AWS", which will never, ever happen. The President of the company quit because of the stupidity of their current strategy. They haven't innovated or created anything genuinely useful in several years -- they mostly survive by exploiting existing customers, successfully suing other companies, and buying out companies that are actually creating things.

-Just a toxic environment overall. I was depressed while I worked here -- I now work for a smaller company and am drastically happier and healthier.  Awful people, awful product, awful company. Get it on your resume and then get out.

review_title: Old reviews and ratings are outdated ........Company has deteriorated drastically
pros:
- Good for women ( in the select teams though)  who want to work FROM home (like attending meetings), while also working FOR home (say, cooking/washing utensils in the background while attending the meetings)

- Also good for men (in the select team), who have a working spouse and one of them need to reach home early to pick -up kids from the school bus

-- Also good for anyone who needs a brand name for future jobs prospects (as long as you don't commit a career-suicide by staying more than 2-3 years in Oracle)

- Multiple resources for free learning if you have time. Also options  to nominate yourself for soft-skills training

- Process-oriented company, so you learn the development methodologies by actually using them against just theoretical knowledge.

- The quality of the recruitments are good. So most people are pleasant to work with.
cons:
(1) Unfortunately,  the rating here average both the recent and very old reviews, so the fact that the company has deteriorated in the last 5-7 years is not apparent

(2) There is NO CONCEPT OF HIKES once you join. Your first hike may itself get delayed by as much as 2.5-3.5 years or even beyond. Here are the reason:
(i ) An employee not considered for the first hike after joining
(ii) Hikes, in general, come one in 2 to 2.5 years (or more in troubled times)
(iii) Not everyone gets a hike. The ratio is 70:30 or 60: 40 (So in a team of 10 employees, only about 6-7 get hike, 3-4 dont). Generally, new employees are targeted to deprive them of hikes, since they are still to prove themselves, but it also depends on the manager's favoritism. Remember if you miss an increment cycle then the next one comes only after 2-2.5+ years. So how much do you lag behind the market now?
(iv) Even if you get a hike it is mostly a single digit (sometimes as low as 3-5%). But the company has manipulated everyone psychologically. For example, those getting a (minuscule) hike are so happy being considered for the hike that they forget that their peers in other companies getting much HIGHER increments EVERY year.
(v) The company fires a number of employees just before the hikes, so even those employees that don't get hikes (some times for 5-7 years at a stretch) are happy to save their job. Working in Oracle for more than 3 years has already made you misfit for the world outside

(3 The same above logic for Bonus and Shares. Mostly managers favorites ( mostly decided by the nationality/regional/language commonality) make it to the list..Other are filtered out from Bonus and Shares,

(4) There are frequent job-losses, but they are managed smartly so it does not make it to the media. Only those figures where a country's government mandatorily requires retrenchment figures land in the press. (For example, say the companies have employees across 250  floors of office space globally with a seating capacity of 500 employees on each floor, and 50  people are retrenched  DAILY from random floors. Would anyone notice?  But what is the lay-off  figure for a month ? Especially since no communications are made to other employees, as most think that the employee is working from home.

(5) While the old reviews may talk otherwise, but because of job-loss panic, there is no  work-life balance. In fact because of the  recent mass-scale job losses people volunteer to stretch themselves.

(6) You are a misfit for the industry once you work here for more than 3 years. So you can take a clerical salary for the rest of your work-life and pray that you are not a victim of retrenchment in between...... It works this way- Despite aggressive press claims, the company lags behind in technology by 5-7 years from the industry. However, you cannot upgrade yourself by self-initiative either, since there is a heavy workload every day due to the panic over probable job-losses.  So each future year you are behind the industry further, leading to a VICIOUS Cycle.. It is like joining an underworld gang : you can only join but you cannot leave.

(7) Though outwardly the company has pleasant culture, but no tricks from passive-aggression remain untouched inside.

review_title: Oracle a great place to work if you're in the right team.
pros:
Oracle offers excellent benefits including: life, accident, medical, vision, dental and LTD insurance; discounts at many retailers and with most auto manufactures.  Oracle allows teleworking within many organizations.  It is generally well inclined towards maintaining a positive work/life balance by allowing flexible work hours depending on role and a substantial allocation of vacation time, starting with 3 weeks and moving up to 4.5 weeks after 3 years of service.  Additionally Oracle provides up to $6000 annually in tuition reimbursement for those seeking college degrees relevant to their jobs roles.

Depending on the organization, Oracle can be a very positive place to work with exposure to excellent peers and management.  The wealth of industry experience is very broad and it's a pleasure working with professionals that really know their stuff.  Many teams have a great deal of autonomy and are able to do things their own way as long as the job gets done.
cons: Oracle is very slow to change at a fundamental level.  Despite the many acquisitions, the culture has changed very little and in most cases it has changed for the worse.   There is very little opportunity for career growth for most management as the majority of new roles appear to go to senior and executive level management from each of the acquisitions.  There is a major problem with the "out of sight out of mind" mentality, as the vast majority of promotions that do occur tend to happen to staff and managers based at HQ.  There's also many "Little Larrys" at Oracle, executives who tend to micro manage to a level so far beneath their station that it often gums up the works.   There's also a lot of vaporware internally within Oracle in terms of projects and management frameworks that have failed to deliver anything of real value to internal employees.  There are many little empires within Oracle, which tend to waste resources through significant redundancy of work that could be done far more efficiently in a shared environment.

Team members spanning from different parts of the globe make it easy to have flexible work hours and work from home a few days a week. Other employee benefits, such as cafeterias, huge gym including sports facility like basketball, cricket, badminton, swimming, plus regular health and other information sessions help the employees with their day to day life. Management and other senior employees are very technically sound and great educators for less experienced people. Job at Oracle is great for your first job as well as for experienced people. Overall, it is a very strong and stable company. Moreover, internal transfer within the company to different groups is very common. So, it is easy to move around as per your liking and comfort. Another positiveis the diverse culture. At the HQ the employees celebrate all important festivals around the world like from China and India.
cons: Downsides depends and varies by group. Some managers are very demanding and it is difficult to satisfy them no matter how hard you work. But, that would be the case in any company where such managers are. While team spread globally does provide flexibility and work from home opportunities, but some phone conference times could be odd to accomodate people in different time zones. With flexible work hours, comes the disadvantage of having to work over the weekends sometimes. If you are given a short task on a Friday and you are expected to finish by early next week, what other choice would you have? But, this greatly varies across groups. Being a large corporation, the management hierarchy is quite deep, making it harder to get paid what you really deserve. Overall, the compensation is about the average market rate. However, the upsides clearly outweigh the downsides.

cons: Environment is not very friendly.  More senior engineers and engineers can treat "lower" engineers very dismissively.  Not much opportunities for career advancement, as the database team is very mature.

pros: sun's engineering jobs are so exciting because various new technology and products both s/w and h/w come up all the time. I'm very satisfied with working at technology rich company.
cons:
Sun don't have stable management strategy. So any new product releases and new technology
will be always changed. From customer's site planning point of view, it was so inconvenient.

review_title: It wasn't what I expected. The job description did not really match the actual job.

cons: Huge company with a lot of bureaucracy. Some of the web based products are archaic. If you're looking to focus on usability and user experience, this is not the place to be.

review_title: Great place to throttle every desire to do neat things!

review_title: An ever expanding but well-run, profitable company holds major opportunities for career advancement
job_title: Oracle Direct Sales Account Executive in Boston, MA
pros: No shortage of opportunities to make a name for yourself and get a promotion within the sale organization.  I work with qualified team members - management does a good job of hiring worthy talent.  Financial stability and job security.
cons: No annual merit-based wage increases.  External candidates most often get hired at a higher salary than Oracle's internal candidates who are promoted from within, which isn't very fair.

pros: The work is interesting.  There is a lot to learn.  The technology you work with is often leading edge.  Most of the people are fun to work with and helpful.
cons:
You have to deal with lots of arrogant people.  Projects are not well structured.  Requirements are added and changed very late in the development cycle.

Sometimes it can be difficult to get the information that you need from other groups.

review_title: Can be OK for a large company -- what you make it
pros: Lots of different things going on, with some areas pretty reasonable. You can look for the right fit without having to leave the company. Pretty secure employment (for product development lines of business -- maybe not so much in sales).
cons: Lots of politics, which may not be surprising for a large company, especially one that has grown via acquisitions. Stagnant pay, which can be frustrating when the company performs well. Product development moves at a slow pace for a lot of reasons -- definitely not a nimble startup.

pros: As with many companies, your career with Oracle is completely based on who you know and the network that you build.  Hard work and stellar achievements will take you far but you need to align with the correct individuals and ensure that someone is paying attention to your hard work and results.
cons: As Oracle has grown so has the red tape.  I can only speak to working in the consulting arm of the business but travel planning because less streamlined as additional policies were put in place to govern the corporation as a whole.

pros:
Good team members
co-operative management up to certain level in hierarchy

Salary is pathetic except the initial package
Irrespective of promotions no increase in salary 
Shopping spree (acquiring companies through out my stay did not help any employee) many left in frustration - Absolutely slow decision making top management

review_title: Great Job to start your sales career - Oracle Direct - Enterprise

Commission can be delayed. 
High-Turn Over.
Politics between Inside and Outside sales.

review_title: Great technology and ability to work with the largest firms in the world

review_title: I am not very satisfied with the overall prospects at Oracle
job_title: Senior Manager QA in Belmont, CA
pros: There is very little to say anything positive about Oracle.
cons: As an employer, Oracle is never considered as 'employee friendly' but only 'executive management' friendly. Coming in as an employee thru the acquisition, there was always a sense of dissent from the management of whatever we do and disdain from the immediate higher up of the management chain. Without understanding either the product and/or its capabilities, nuances etc etc., the acquired employees were always a subject of the 'blame game'. This certainly does not help the morale of the team that I was supposed to manage and deliver results by working your 'read end' off!!!

review_title: Pretty Good if you're on the right team with the right manager
pros: If you like corporate life, you'll like Oracle. Global company so lots of opportunities and through line of mission statement. Fabulous benefits, decent pay and excellent resources. Stability to an extent (They do outsource sometimes). If you're on a key team you have many opportunities to move forward or to a different team for a better position. They love hiring internals for promotional moves and general openings and encourage you to keep learning new things to increase your skill set. Some great people and decent office environment.
cons: The level of middle management is hit or miss. Get the right manager and it's smooth sailing, get the wrong one and it can be a real nightmare. Raises are difficult to come by in most cases, they tend to low ball positions and if you're hired you will find it very difficult to secure a raise even if you move to a different position that might pay more - again depends on the manager. If you leave and try and come back they will try to give you the same salary as when you left/were let go until 2 years have passed. Training is also hit or miss depending on the team and for a software company - their software and bandwidth is extremely frustrating at times. At my location there was only one on site tech and tickets seemed to mount up. Equipment was decent but not great and the culture can be ridiculously gossip driven. Also way too political - if you earn the respect of the right people you advance despite lacking actual skill, if you don't have anyone behind you, good luck moving up.

review_title: some good, some bad like any large company but take advantage of what is offered
job_title: Customer Support Director in New York, NY
pros:
You can probably fly under the radar and stay here for a very long time.  
You have a lot of opportunity for training and you should be able to move around to other areas if you'd like (sometimes that's harder than it needs to be but it does happen).
Benefits are great.
There is some flexibility that allows for a decent work-life balance but most of that was just changed.
cons:
Management growth potential in Support is stagnant - no one moves out or up it seems.  Sometimes there are lateral projects given to the stars
Available time to do training or anything strategic is limited by escalation fire fighting and last minute urgent requests.
Managers and Directors have no power - all dictates come from above and are often misguided.
Lack of vision and leadership at the exec level - focus on minutiae and micromanagement. 
Understanding of how support should be structured to deal with the diverse product families is completely missing at the Exec level and anyone at a lower level who knows is powerless to make any changes.
You never know from year to year if there will be raises and/or bonuses and even when there are, there is never enough money to go around so there are many people without raises for years.

review_title: A good manager hires a good employee and gets out of their way
job_title: Software Engineer II in Bedford, MA
pros:
-Little micro-management. You are given a task and it is up to manage your time to do it.
-Very good work culture. No cut throat environment.
cons:
-Slowness typical of big companies.
-Career growth can be very slow depending on what group you are on.
-Self service employee tools can be counter productive.

pros: Great flexibility with ability to work from home and even in other countries. Very relaxed work environment mostly.
cons: From my experience and everyone I have spoken to - it is almost impossible to get decent raises or bonuses without leaving or changing team. Can be very frustrating seeing employees doing very little and getting paid more when you are working hard and producing work getting rave reviews with little rewards.

review_title: Great benefits, great training opportunities, immense resources
pros: Almost no limit to what you can learn here.  Legions of very smart people, loads of great training available, flexible working conditions (remote / virtual), nice offices if you don't work virtual.
cons: Very self-service (automated systems, difficult to get a human to help you with benefits, internal systems, etc.). Sales teams compete and are often not well-coordinated on large accounts.  As with most large companies, can be very bureaucratic with long, complex processes.

review_title: Looks good, pays decent, but slow growth. Good place to work though
pros:
You can get to know a lot of ppl who are awesome at what they do and get their help if you want to really give your everything to get higher.
Flexible timings and work. In my case, i was able to work when i liked and i never had a fixed 'in-time' or 'out-time'.
Work is chill most of the time! except one or two days in a month when there is a priority bug! nothing wrong there!
An ocean of learning opportunity with oracle University. It is free for you and you can almost go for all the trainings that are relevant to your work, or if your manager is okay with it!
The company is doing well! if you are thinking about job security, then this is the place! they wont fire you that easily! one in a 10000 gets fired once in 2-3 years. Those are good odds.
cons:
no perks whatsoever! if you think the points mentioned in 'Pros' are good, then that's all you will get.
If you don't ask, you are almost forgotten. 
The HR and the manager both point fingers at each other if we express displeasure with compensation.
Young college hires will get the market corrected salary every year! But its almost a miracle if they correct your salary according to theirs!
Even your VP if he comes and you talk to him about compensation, he will point his finger towards Larry Ellison or Safra Catz !

cons: Promotion is a challenge, as being great at your job is no enough, it is more to whom you know. Salary increases rare, requiring a promotion or leaving the group / organization one currently works in.

review_title: Great Salary · Great personal growth · BAD Management
pros:
Salary
Healthcare Benefits
Investment Portfolio Fund (In charge of events and birthday presents)
cons:
Life - Work Balance
Management Bias
A LOT of constant pressure and being fired is always a constant menace.
Database is the ONLY product with good sales. 

Oracle is a great company, I did love the pressure they placed on myself, because they forced me to become more efficient and to worry a lot about my prospection process and who I wanted to be and do. 

The big problem with Oracle are 2 things, management and HR. Manager will pretty much step on you every single time they have a chance, and to be honest to my reader mine WASN'T like this, yet as soon as he switched to another company i started seeing outside the bubble he had created for us. It is often to see people worried or crying about getting fired, because for Oracle if you ain't doing your quota you are not worth their time, and you'll be on the street by the end of the Q. 

Does this sound too extreme? Well..that's the true way it is. 
So why do you stand up to this? The payment is good. 
Why is HR another problem? Because there is little investment on the situation of their employees, and before even considering switching you to another manager or product, getting rid of you is a better choice.

They promote people without increasing salary (not sure why people accept those promotions).

review_title: Flexible Schedule, Good People, Loads of Bureaucracy
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Redwood City, CA
pros:
Overall, I enjoyed my time at Oracle but it was wasn't a company I would ever call home. 

The company is huge, so I can't speak to all of it but within my team:
 
- My schedule was very flexible
- Lots of work from home options
- Decent benefits including 401K matching
- Very much a outcomes based team, not a "butts in seats" team
- Decent pay (I've heard a lot of rumblings and jokes about lack of raises)
- Good people, including immediate managers. (Mine were all excellent!)
cons:
Considering most of the team is distributed throughout the world, it was very hard to get things done and everything moves painfully slow. This might be a plus for many but I'm anxious to get my work done so it became frustrating at times. 

Most companies struggle with creating an efficient process, but I found the same problems at Oracle that I had within much younger and smaller companies. It was often hard to do quality work because of too many cooks in the kitchen or inability to get access to information)

The internal tools to do anything (order supplies, complete evaluations, download files, etc.) are hard to use. It took me two days to figure out how to get the right cable to hook up my monitor. Figuring out who to talk to regarding HR matters such as benefits also took an unnecessarily long time.

Vacation policy is low IMO for the tech industry which is 2 weeks, including a mandatory 4 days over the holidays.

Very little opportunity for traditional growth for certain roles. Of course, you can always be proactive and speak up. They will listen.

This is neither a pro or a con, but I feel the need to include it anyway. Oracle has very little of what I would call company culture. It's a very "do your job and go home" company.

pros: I was recently hired as a Pre-Sales Solution Consultant with NetSuite and I am very excited to start working with the PreSales Team. Cloud-based ERP for SMEs is the key in having an efficient business operations from Financial Reporting to the entire Revenue and Purchasing Cycle and NetSuite is the leader in the Industry.
cons:
Acquisition by Oracle may have a downside risk due to shift in top management style of doing business.  

But overall, acquisition by Oracle as a leader in its own Industry, can be a positive impact for NetSuite in the long run.

pros: I worked for Oracle for almost 19 years.  I loved the people that I worked with. The health benefits were incredible-nothing comparable that i have found.
cons: The environment is very stressful and although the corporate line is that "working in excess of 50 hrs per week is rare." This is totally untrue.  Average work week is between 60-70 hours per week for Salary employees.

pros: Great Place learn and be with the leader when started in year 2010. Earned Excellent compensation with an outstanding work life balance.
cons: Continuous denial (cloud computing) by Larry & Team has coated Oracle dearly, some of the best sales folks have already quit Oracle and I would rate current sales and product development team below par, not at all bright either in approach nor temperament

pros:
Oracle is undeniably a market leader with a fierce appetite to continue to grow and remain a leading driver in the transformation of the technology marketplace to the cloud-based model.  Oracle is leveraging it's vast resources to build viable solutions for any and all cloud plays, large and small from IASS, to PAAS to SAAS to full-stack solutions.
As an Oracle employee, your career is in your own hands; there are ample opportunities to  learn and grow if you are willing to invest the time and take the initiative.  Oracle provides a wide range of training and career development resources, but it is all self-service; it's up you you to navigate the vast Oracle world and make sense of it.  I have worked with many exceptional people here at Oracle and most colleagues are eager to help and work together toward common goals.  Oracle can afford to offer competitive compensation and offers a better than average benefits package.
cons: Oracle has grown relentlessly by acquisition for years so it seems there's always something new to integrate and adapt to as they continue to assimilate everything in their path.  Oracle is aggressively shifting from on prem hardware and software to The Cloud and any transition that significant is disruptive.  Constant growth and change in the past few years has come with the continual spectre of RIFs and Reorgs. Oracle is very process driven so almost everything has to follow format and even the smallest exceptions requires executive approval.  On the other hand integration of new acquisitions rarely smooth, so frustration can build when process and progress collide.

review_title: Stability that comes with a price...
pros: It's possible to build a fulfilling career at Oracle where the company's financial stability can provide opportunities to innovate and try new things.  I've worked with great people and great leaders up to the VP level.  In my group bonuses have generally been consistent.  Often times it feels like I am working for a very well-funded start up.
cons: While bonuses can be good, they can also be significantly impacted by factors outside of our direct control, so even when you're doing everything right and having significant impact on the business, the criteria can be so far removed from your influence that you can be left feeling powerless.  Similarly, although there is a meaningful effort in play to improve talent management across the company, the impact of these efforts takes too long to be felt among the employees, leading to lower morale and, once more, lack of control over one's destiny.  You go through a process, develop objectives, work with your managers and then find that things move so slowly and without meaningful criteria for advancement or promotion that what starts as a positive, hopeful experience results in a negative outcome.  Oracle is slow to recognize the need to provide salary increases and promotions.  This makes it difficult to retain good people.

review_title: Could Really Be A Lot Better - Sometimes Not Sure What To Think
pros:
- Oracle offers excellent benefits, good pay and a stable work environment.  In my position, I work from home so that's really nice.  

- I think my management team means well and does their best to support their team with what they have to work with.  

- I think Oracle is trying to help their employees grow and learn more through the use of training tools offered online such as books and video training.  I've recently seen information to help ou plan your career out.  This helps a bit

- In my area, Oracle is rapidly expanding so the there's never a shortage of work.  This can be good and bad.

- For the most part, I get a long with everyone and my internal customers appreciate my help.
cons:
- Oracle is a complex company with many moving parts.  This can make understanding the big picture difficult at times.

- Sometimes upper management can seem a bit bureaucratic at times and it can be difficult to get your ideas or concerns attention

- Internal career advancement can be difficult.  I've noticed that applying for a position internally can be surprising hard to work through.  Over time, I've noticed that opportunities I applied for will not even get an answer.  I believe if you apply internally, you should at least get an acknowledgement detailing why you didn't get the position and what you can do to improve.  

- Communications can be poor.  There's way too much email.  Somehow you end up being subscribed to too many email distribution groups.  Really, I feel like I'm drowning in email.  I receive no fewer than 300 emails a day.  I hate looking at my email.

- Everything is "urgent" and "top priority."  Hardly anything is low priority.  I don't understand why my team's work is a "blocker" to other team's projects when we get a ticket on the same day.  Some days, it's really overwhelming.  I don't need reminders of how backed up the ticket queue is either.  I know what work I need to do.

- It's hard to get a straight answer on procedures.  Ask 3 people, you will most likely get 3 completely different answers.  Some documentation is there but it's loosely organized.  It's up to all team members to maintain documentation.  I think it makes a mess and only confuses people.  

- Oracle is very strict with change management but so restrictive, it feels like we have one hand tied behind our backs to get the job done.

pros:
Big company nice to have on your CV
Malaga is a nice location for weather and life quality
cons:
The job is not in line with the job specification, you don't do sales but only reporting and sales operations. 
Too many policies and tools that don't work, you can go for a walk while the CRM opens an opportunity.
You receive obsolete data within your territory which is not helping you at all.
It's Oracle and not client orientated, you compete with other sales rep on the same client.
They will make up any sort of policy to not pay you commissions.

review_title: There’s a reason the bronto is extinct
pros:
Good money
Great people (most of them)
Looks good on a resume
cons: Bronto is the unwanted stepchild of Oracle. Through acquisitions, oracle has stamped its name onto Bronto... yet it is the furthest thing from a truly oracle company. Bronto doesn’t sell oracle products nor could any employee tell you a thing about oracle, and netsuite for that matter. It’s a great software tool in a very saturated market. Their value pitch is dated and sounds like every other company’s in the space. They lose consistently in deals for one main reason, price. Constantly prospects will voice how they love the software and the sales rep, but they aren’t willing to donate a kidney to send sophisticated emails. What company puts tens of thousands of dollars aside to shoot out emails? Not many. Bronto executives pride themselves on calling the software “best in breed” yet even when they say it you question if they believe it. Its sad when you attend a company meeting to praise the successes and only 2-5 people hit their number in the entire new business side of the organization. A sales rep basically knows going into the account executive role that he or she won’t hit goal, but it would be cool to close a deal or two before leveraging oracle to go somewhere better. Somewhere happier. Somewhere with more realistic goals and prides themselves on not just how they support their customers, but their actual staff. It’s a game of numbers to help certain executives hit their goal to look good. They could care less about their employees. In my time there I watched the best of the best  drop like flies from each sector of the company. Ask about our fossils page. It updates just as often as Donald Trump’s Twitter. The majority of sales directors are talented, strong leaders. Yet their sdrs are being ruled out of fear and empty threats with unattainable quotas. Micromanaging has become quite the new trend. If you care to visit the beautiful office, you’ll be overwhelmed with the funk in the air filled of unhappiness and resentment. Who knows what oracle and netsuite have in store for this place? Something needs to change.

pros:
-  Flexibility,
- Good work place environment
- This could be seen as good or bad, workload isn't stimulating or challenging but it allows you the freedom to develop other skills / free time.

cons:
- Your salary goes to Oracle to die. There are no annual reviews, no hikes, your starting salary will remain the same for years and years until you decide to leave. They know this, and they're okay with this. I've been told by Directors that Oracle is a learning experience, and you should take that experience elsewhere to get a pay rise. This should be unacceptable, but it's the not-so-secret secret that everyone knows and begrudgingly accepts.
- The freedom you enjoy to develop yourself and how you develop your work, as well as the great environment this creates, which is very important, is also used against you because upper management makes it clear it's their strategy to justify not increasing salaries.
- Because of this, there's some upward mobility because tenured people will leave sooner or later but there's also a big waiting list. If you've got the talent but there's people who have been there for half a decade, waiting for a chance, then tough luck, get in line. There's no clear career path and there's no intention for you to have one.
- HR doesn't exist, unless things get serious. You will never have contact with an HR representative in your tenure at Oracle, barring the starting period, and you should be thankful if you don't because HR is in place to protect the company and only the company.
- Upper management is an absolute old boy's club, completely out of touch. Their strategies are not working for many years now and Oracle is running out of small, profitable companies to buy. It is dying a slow death and they won't be able to afford losing tenured people in the future, or stop ignoring said acquisitions and customers.

+ The big red Oracle on your resume.

cons:
+ Completely top-down, command and control environment. Good ideas only allowed to flow down from above. They spray to keep the grass-roots dead.
+ Management from acquired companies fill up middle management layer so no promi
tion opportunities for front-line managers.
+ Job title inflation. "Promotions" do not come with raises, its cheap to give someone a new title even though their boss, reports, job description, or responsibilties do not change.

+ Other reviews about nice facilities only applies to HQ offices.
+ Paid for 40 hours, work for 60 hours and expected to accomplish 80 hours worth of work.
+ No vision. Management focus very mecurial and ADHD, very reactionary and afraid to take risks and support their people.

review_title: Would only work there again if my family were starving--literally starving
pros: Excellent compensation, great benefits, nice gym, pleasing campus, good food options, and, because it is a desirable employer, you generally end up working with competent/intelligent colleagues. Also, it is a refreshingly international campus, with many foreign languages to be heard as you walk around.
cons: I was warned about Oracle's multitudes of miserable employees, but I refused to believe that there were no good departments in such a large and sure-to-be-multifaceted company.  And perhaps there are harmonious departments that run smoothly enough, but my experience sadly fit in with the legends circulating in the valley. I witnessed an outrageous degree of politics (every company suffers from this, but Oracle antics exceed the usual). Morale always seemed to be dropping. And it was difficult to simply to our job. Two VPs splitting control over the same product were vying over our little group as just one pawn leading to ultimate control of said product. In vying for our group, both had a hand in almost destroying it. The petty and destructive behavior was completely tolerated in the higher rungs of the organization: the executive VPs were aware of the warfare and did nothing to promote productivity. In the org structure, our little group was always placed under a branch that made it difficult to accomplish anything. I've never had to jump through so many hoops to simply perform the task I had been asked to perform to begin with. I came in so very proud to be an Oracle employee. I recall having the "Sunday blues" with other jobs, but with Oracle, I had the blues on the eve of every workday.

I also think Larry and Safra are cool.  They are sharp people and have kept the company on top.   Middle management blames these two for all that goes bad--the reality is that they are not the problem, it is the middle-managers who use Larry and Safra as an excuse not to address their own bad management practices.  If Larry and Safra knew the games played, the way salespeople get screwed, the way that middle management blames them for everything, things would get better.
cons: Oracle caps the earnings of their sales reps at any one account.  After you hit 250% of your quote, they drop you to like 1%.  Management rips on sales people; they think they earn too much money.  They think management gives a lot of help on big deals so reps should be capped.  Big deals are few and far between, territories are getting smaller, and it is getting more bureaucratic.  The morale is horrible, and many reps continue to leave.
