pros: Work life balance, average pay et al. Good place for freshers.
cons:
As most of the product based companies are trimming employee size,it's best to avoid these companies at the moment as you never know when the axing starts. Joining at this time would like  hanging around with a double edged sword.
                 The company is only surviving by making acquisitions for the last decade. No innovation has come from Oracle alone for many years.

pros:
The people and next 3 to 4 levels of management are great. They used to be able to have autonomy to run their business the way they wanted. They understood their organization and customer and Oracle was a well oiled machine. Of course this will depend on teams. Some teams are better than others.  

I give Oracle 2 stars because it can still be salvaged if management wakes up and listens to the customers and employees on the front lines.
cons:
Oracle used to have the best culture but management is destroying it and trying to remake themselves into a Cloud company. They can become a cloud company and keep the culture but I am afraid that it is too late. 

You will never ever ever ever ever get a raise here. Even if you get promoted it is highly unlikely. Make sure whatever you negotiate when being hired is what you can live with. It's not like a typical company where you can expect to make more later. 

Oracle is very micromanaged these days. Managers do not have the ability to do much to help you. Their hands are tied behind their backs and they are handcuffed. 

Besides raises, which you will never ever see, benefits are slowly being eroded while upper management increases their pay and perks. There once was a car allowance for some employees but it was slashed. Some pay was slashed. Vacation days were forced to be taken at the end of the year (3-4 days). Internet reimbursement was taken away. Mobile-Wifi was taken away. 

It's almost as if they don't want their employees to be productive and to be able to work. The support the organization needs to survive is being taken out from under it. It's all about cost cutting and it is impacting the organization's ability to be able to deliver results.

Seasoned employees are being forced out and being replaced with millennials, most who have no clue what they are doing. They robo call very loyal customers to death and make them very annoyed with the company to the point sentiment is shifting. Turnover has definitely increased for seasoned worked and even the new millennials. I guess the company is ok with this?

Bottom line, morale is in the toilet and I don't think management cares.

pros: Strong class-of bond and cool peers. Success is often luck-based, so if you're in a lucky territory or have a good relationship with your sales team, you hardly need to work more than a few hours a day to show great numbers. If you do really well, you will get promoted in a year.
cons:
Where do I begin? I was very motivated to do well as a fresh college graduate. However, I quickly learned that success at Oracle means learning to play their game and has NOTHING to do with you own abilities. I was lucky to have a good manager and team, but that doesn't mask the fact that 80% of my time was spent logging pointless "interactions" and bombarding customers with unwanted messaging/information. Calling fake companies and phone numbers to make your metrics look good is a very common practice. The amount of false information put into the system is unbelievable - I don't know how this company hasn't collapsed already. 

There is also a very "fratty" culture. There were a few times I felt uncomfortable with the highly unprofessional conversations, and more than a few times where I felt uncomfortable at work because someone was make unwanted advances on myself or a female coworker. No one is invested in building the company, but rather in making money themselves or bettering there career. There's a lot of back-stabbing and sneaking around, even on the same team. Don't work here if you want your hard work to be reflected in the company. 

Perhaps the worst disappointment of all is the pay. Some people can make great money here, but they are very few and far between. The recruiters flat-out lied about how much money you can actually make, since commissions are pooled. If Oracle doesn't hit it's number (which it almost never does), you will NOT make your full commission or even sniff anything close. I consistently exceeded my number by almost double every quarter and hardly saw anything in commission. Management tries to justify poor commissions by saying "it's fine, you're just learning and you'll be promoted in the year." The truth is, being promoted to a sales representative at Oracle is an even worse place to be in. Unless you have an extremely lucky territory or fall into a deal cycle, you risk not closing anything for your first year (or more). This means you will be living on your base salary of $53,000 with no hope for commission. During my time at Oracle, I have seen only a couple of deals close in my entire division.

I feel like the local management cares about their reputation, and not of their subordinates.

cons:
The con's outweigh the pro's... 
-No room to move. They promise a career path, and pending on which satellite or campus you work, it may be there. But not all of the locations are created equal. 

-The benefits are so good, they almost trap you there. 

-No pay raises. I worked there for some time and I never got a pay raise. Even though my reviews were all above company standards.

-The training they promise is empty. While they hype it up to the best thing ever, their 'Oracle University' amounts to nothing more than Youtube quality videos. Not to mention, they make you pay for the classes out of pocket. 

-Direct and upper management are confusing and non-transparent. They will tell you nothing. Whatever they do tell you is convoluted and in most cases, wrong. 

-Management will make horrific decisions and moves. Mostly in the name of a budget, but in the long run, it just causes more problems and costs more money.

-Morale is sour. Nobody wants to work because there's no incentive. 

-If you don't work on a major campus or at a larger satellite, you will not be treated like a full Oracle Employee. I have several other friends who work for the company across the US, and they are treated much better than my location.

friendly peers

pros: Great flexible benefits, great if you want to work from home and choose your hours. Great if you enjoy politics or just want to cruise along without much engagement.
cons: Little strategic direction resulting in many conflicting priorities. Very process heavy. Short-term attitude means constant firefighting without addressing the real problems. review_title: The worst place I've ever worked

pros: About the only positive was my manager's liberal attitude to signing off expenses. I'm genuinely struggling to find anything else positive to say.
cons: If you want poor salary, no career progression, slowly eroding benefits, no pay rises and zero bonus.......work for Oracle. The only way to work your way up is to leave and come back. review_title: Less stressful than other tech companies, but at a cost

pros:
Work life balance

No cultural activity.

pros: Width and breadth of products and  exposure to huge variety of customers.  Challenging  work particularly during this transition from on-prem to Cloud. Get to work on latest technologies. Deep pockets can afford to more research and development.

review_title: The Good Bad and the Ugly

Excellent benefits.
Great people regardless of the company culture.

Dog eat dog culture.

Strategies change regularly and who gets to play is often vague.
The competition has lesser products but wins more often due to internal Oracle competition.

review_title: Not a bad company, but stuck in the past

cons: The company doesn't attract best talent; very corporate working environment with a lot of inflexibility and mediocre management. Extremely aggressive sales force. Salary and benefits are average.

pros: If you are the type of person who likes to take the initiative to learn different technologies, Oracle would be great for you. You have loads of training at your finger tips. cons: Negotiate hard coming in. Since Oracle provides a lucrative bonus structure, they do not give significant raises to your base pay.

pros: Brand recognition, technology depth, earnings potential, fat expense account. Oracle was fair with my customers, unlike another *large* software company I worked in which reps made their number on customer audits.

pros: Stable environment. Shorter work hour than startup or others in the area. Nice Gym. Good to prepare for retirement.

As said before good to be there if you are "in" retirement. Not good if you want to do something great and being appreciated.

pros: Excellent and flexible benefits package, very flexible working practices with extensive use of technology such as remote working video conferring etc. Huge resources and plenty of support and help available. Plenty of opportunities to progress career internally.

review_title: Stable environment, shows some signs of age
pros: Oracle has always provided the freedom for talented and skilled people to make a case for doing things their own way.      Flagship health insurance.
cons: Too many middle-aged managers.  Upper management is filled with people who aren't leaving unless they die, so opportunities for advancement are few and far between.  At the lower end, they fill positions with "lowcost headcount".  This produces near-constant churn because they leave as soon as they build up skills and can go elsewhere for more money.

review_title: Valuable experience at the beginning, frustrating as the time passes.

pros:
The pros are:  
the benefits, 
the resources at your disposal, 
some corporate events, 
food is quite cheap and relatively good and diverse,
If you like self-service it’s nice as well and you can get some incentives (refer people, buy vacations, and get discounts)…

If you’re not necessarily skilled or good at your job, and you can slip through the net and get some commissions by chance. For some cases, people were lucky enough to be at the right place in the right time and get a big paycheck – before leaving, and others have been here for nearly 2 years without closing any deals. 

Oracle is sometimes closer to the social welfare or a casino than a proper IT company made of talented salespeople. It's a HUGE lottery.
cons:
I’ve never seen a corporation like this. Let’s try to be objective and go through this step-by-step:

•	Getting to Oracle: scam
Their recruiters are like a huge propaganda department. Someone from some place will contact you by phone, tell you they have a golden opportunity for you and they will invite you to an “assessment center”. They’ll tell you it’s better to do it ASAP as it’s “one of the last” to take place (actually they take place every month or so). You will have to do a PowerPoint (why me, why oracle, why this job) and you have to sell yourself. Basically most of the people in the assessment center get an offer, half of the time if people don’t join it’s because they refuse.
Note: If you’re lucky enough to belong to a strong market (Dutch, German or Scandinavian...), you probably will be able to skip that and be recruited directly through the phone or almost, it happened sometimes.
Beware to have correct data on your resume as they check through their screening partner. Don’t be too excited about their relocation package, because they will hunt you down if you want to leave to pay it back.

•	Starting at Oracle: DIY
So, you come at your desk, they give you a laptop, a to-do-list, and here you go, it’s all about DIY. Self-service pushed to the extreme. Nobody tells you if what to do is right, but they will tell you if it’s wrong. No real on-boarding plan, you spend 3 weeks watching videos and you have to order your own screens, mouse, keyboard etc.
You probably won’t even know in which team you belong to nor meeting your manager before a few days for those who are lucky, and it can take a whole quarter to get a team – they call it “overhires”. You’re a collateral damage of Oracle Direct strategy. It’s not your fault but that’s the way it is.

•	Training at Oracle: Going away to the college
Ok so after your 3 weeks of watching random videos. You have their 2 weeks on-site training in fancy hotels with people coming from Dubai, Malaga, Berlin, Prague… it’s cool to meet those people. The first week is a training (boring) about sales techniques, and the one-man-show of some american salesguy who teaches you how to cold-call in such a way it would portray Barack Obama as an introvert. Not very applicable elsewhere than in Texas or LA..
The second week you have presentations to do (individual or group presentations), assessments consisting of a sales call with a scenario.

This was back in the days, now it consists of 4 weeks in a remote place in Kildare where you have to come every day (3 hours driving in and out) where you have to make presentations every weeks in front of your group (120 people attend it) and you’re put under pressure for these 4 weeks as there are different tiers (Q1 / Q2 / Q3 / Q4) and from this grading system your evolution will depend a lot. As you’re back in school, you have presentations to prepare in the evening for the day after so you won’t finish off before 9 or 10 pm actually.

•	Working at Oracle: Hardcore

Well… for those who have a manager or a territory from the beginning, which is basically the purpose they were hired, lucky them. For the other over-hires
Their CRM is very slow, messy, not intuitive and too much data are duplicated. It’s hard to have 360 view on what's going on in your territory / deals.
The sales processes are VERY LONG but it’s not much because of the negotiation / implementation timeframe. Salespeople are fighting internally 90% of the time than against the customers to get discounts from the teams in the states who don’t understand that the products are way above the average in terms of price and there’s a discount in most of the time to get a sell, probably more than 50% or even 60% in many cases.
Oracle is an American company and they are worried about their “branding” and legal issues. When an executive made awkward comments about minorities for joking in a conference, he was quickly urged to apologize for his “sense of humor”, blaming his personality, so let's say they have some issues sometimes but they try to fix it.
The management is inexistent: the company is suffering from its gigantism. Nobody really knows what’s going on and each zone/country/department/team/manager and everybody has a little piece of the puzzle. 
We’ve seen executives being deposed from their position to lower because of the mess created by the wave of resignations, paired with the lack of power to motivate or keep their employees. They always talk about the money, money, MONEY you could make, but they still don’t understand that the targets are unreachable for most of the people except some lucky ones and they lost the trust from their employees and are not credible, or even well-liked… at all.

•	Career Evolution

Managers don’t have power except to annoy you for your KPIs, they won’t help you in designing your career path or go to the frontline to get more realistic targets. They are obeying to those above etc. and don’t even have more visibility on what’s going on than their subordinates.
If you lick the right person’s boots, you can be sure it will pay off almost all of the time, even if you’re not skilled in your job. It’s all about credibility and people don’t check so far the words of the others. It’s easy to smoke managers or others about someone’s performance or suitability for a role.
Oracle is a giant and they are really proud, if not arrogant about that. Such as their CEO, they love to split on the competitors. Most of the income of Oracle comes from their databases business and they are lacking in so many areas that they counterbalance it with the cash flow they invest and companies they acquire. So they will make you believe it’s the time to be in the company (like all the companies do), they will invite the press and even politics to show how many new openings they are responsible of. But they won’t tell that the turnover is just impressive because of the lack of perspectives and work conditions.
If you want to evolve at Oracle, you must leave and come back, they even encourage people to do so they come back with a stronger knowledge and network in exchange of a higher position or paycheck. In the meantime, if you want to work hard and reap the rewards of their work, just go on your way.

•	Leaving Oracle

That's a delicate situation. Many people want to leave actually but they feel stuck because of the relocation package they have to payback (see above in the starting at oracle). Many want to get dismissed and avoid this + get a little money while looking after new jobs. They create and kill jobs and still recruit people but there is not enough place for everybody. that's non-sense. Many people don't dare to tell to the recruiters what's going on because people feel embarassed and ashamed of being victim of such a mess, and this is probably their fault if they're not good enough to hit unrealistic targets (according to the management). Hence the name of the review: " an unconvenient truth"

1. Sometimes you are lfet completely alone and in the dark

pros:
All The managers are highly technical. That makes your job as a developer alot easier, especially when managers know the code so well. They also make it very easy for employees to ramp up. 
The database side of the company is very engineering driven, so lots of space for research.
But i think it comes down to your team.
cons: Things move a little slowly... in terms of reviews, and stuff getting done in general.

review_title: Org better than many others but, not so great to work for

Varied platforms, technologies, industries to choose from
Lot of opportunities to work with cross-functional teams
Centralized employee database making any other emp/group accessible
cons:
Lack of proper support from management
Compensation & Promotions not consistent or dependent with/on work experience or performance 
Flexi timing or work-from-home policy doesn't exist on paper more often than none leading to discrepancies on who is given that benefit and who is not
No proper framework for performance evaluations

pros:

Ever increasing quotas and sales targets (250% increase in the last 4 years) with no increase in benefits or compensation.

review_title: Oracle is a great place to start your career

pros:
Oracle is a good place to work, if you really wanted to grow technically. These are the following pros :
1) Good technical growth
2) chance to work with lit if smart & very experienced people
3) Good management support for highly motivated & enthusiastic candidates
4) Excellent work environment, as managers themselves are very technical.
5) Performance is recognized and rewarded with promotion.
cons: 1) Hike/bonus is normally relatively less, event if you are a outstanding candidate.

pros: The only pro for me is that I like the software I am working with and the clients (in general) - since I can work mostly at client sites and get out of the Oracle office.
cons:
No payrises for several years.
Constant threat of being retrenched.
Very rigid admin systems that don't often work very well.
Most powerful powerful people in the company seem to be admin people, and some of them target individuals for bad treatment.
No consideration at all of work/life balance - for example, making people fly out of work time so that there are only a few hours in a weekend.
They do not even consider the consultants to be human beings....
